review: It was a pain in the rear to set up.  Check the setup requirements, i'm a savvy network administrator and I did not have a single device at home that was capable of setting up the chromecast w/o significant upgrades.  It was further complicated by no broadcasting the SSID of my network.  This required a call to google tech support.  Several days later they sent an e-mail w/ some suggestions, though they seemed stumped.  It mysteriously started working.There is NO user interface whatsoever which is a smidge annoying but it has worked quite reliably since getting past the installation troubles.
author: Matt Monsour

review: Easy to install.Can not view video at HD and full screen.  Video and sound not synced, (think old Godzilla movie with dubbed voices) video drops out and sections of picture go missing.IF I reduce resolution to 144dpi or 240 max these problems disappear.Internet connection is 20mb and WiFi is high band.  Expected a lot more from Google.You get what you pay for, $30 and you get low end video.

review: I bought the Chromecast with the thought that it might be a great little home theater gadget comparable to the Roku but at half the price. I bought into it in the first few days. I've been running it on my office TV since Netflix and YouTube were the only options.It works for what it's designed for, piping internet videos to your TV by using your phone. What it doesn't do well is integrate into a theater or living room set nearly as well.First, the lack of even a basic remote like the Roku has is greatly limiting it's functionality and integration capabilities. You cannot use the Chromecast with a Harmony of URC remote.Second, the software, though improving all the time, isn't as robust as I'd like. It's not uncommon for the phone (acting as remote control) to somehow lose connection to the device and need to be resynchronized. About half the time, this is accompanied by the video stopping. Frustrating and completely lacking in polish.For me, the Roku (which supports far more sources, including Amazon) is the much better choice. For the few extra dollars you get a larger library, a real remote, and a more solid, consistent user experience.
author: M. Barland
